content.text: Python Tuples

content.code_html: mytuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")

content.text: Tuple
Tuples are used to store multiple items in a single variable.
content.html: Tuples are used to store multiple items in a single variable.

content.text: Tuple is one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data, the other 3 are List , Set , and Dictionary , all with different qualities and usage.
content.html: Tuple is one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data, the other 3 are List, Set, and Dictionary, all with different qualities and usage.

content.text: A tuple is a collection which is ordered and unchangeable .
content.html: A tuple is a collection which is ordered and unchangeable.

content.text: Tuples are written with round brackets.
content.html: Tuples are written with round brackets.

content.code_html:
thistuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(thistuple)

content.text: Tuple Items
Tuple items are ordered, unchangeable, and allow duplicate values.
content.html: Tuple items are ordered, unchangeable, and allow duplicate values.

content.text: Tuple items are indexed, the first item has index [0] , the second item has index [1] etc.
content.html: Tuple items are indexed, the first item has index [0], the second item has index [1] etc.

content.text: Ordered
When we say that tuples are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.
content.html: When we say that tuples are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

content.text: Unchangeable
Tuples are unchangeable, meaning that we cannot change, add or remove items after the tuple has been created.
content.html: Tuples are unchangeable, meaning that we cannot change, add or remove items after the tuple has been created.

content.text: Allow Duplicates
Since tuples are indexed, they can have items with the same value:
content.html: Since tuples are indexed, they can have items with the same value:

content.code_html:
thistuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry", "apple", "cherry")
print(thistuple)

content.text: Tuple Length
To determine how many items a tuple has, use the len() function:
content.html: To determine how many items a tuple has, use the len() function:

content.code_html:
thistuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(len(thistuple))

content.text: Create Tuple With One Item
To create a tuple with only one item, you have to add a comma after the item, otherwise Python will not recognize it as a tuple.
content.html: To create a tuple with only one item, you have to add a comma after the item, otherwise Python will not recognize it as a tuple.

content.code_html:
thistuple = ("apple",)
print(type(thistuple))

#NOT a tuple
thistuple = ("apple")
print(type(thistuple))

content.text: Tuple Items - Data Types
Tuple items can be of any data type:
content.html: Tuple items can be of any data type:

content.code_html:
tuple1 = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
tuple2 = (1, 5, 7, 9, 3)
tuple3 = (True, False, False)

content.text: A tuple can contain different data types:
content.html: A tuple can contain different data types:

content.code_html: tuple1 = ("abc", 34, True, 40, "male")

content.text: type()
From Python's perspective, tuples are defined as objects with the data type 'tuple':
content.html: From Python's perspective, tuples are defined as objects with the data type 'tuple':

content.code_html:
mytuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(type(mytuple))

content.text: The tuple() Constructor
It is also possible to use the tuple() constructor to make a tuple.
content.html: It is also possible to use the tuple() constructor to make a tuple.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thistuple = tuple(("apple", "banana", "cherry")) # note the double round-brackets
print(thistuple)

content.code:
thistuple = tuple(("apple", "banana", "cherry")) # note the double round-brackets
print(thistuple)

syntax_highlighting.text:
thistuple = tuple(("apple", "banana", "cherry")) # note the double round-brackets
print(thistuple)

content.code_html:
thistuple = tuple(("apple", "banana", "cherry")) # note the double round-brackets
 print(thistuple)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thistuple = tuple(("apple", "banana", "cherry")) # note the double round-brackets
print(thistuple)

content.text: Python Collections (Arrays)
There are four collection data types in the Python programming language:
content.html: There are four collection data types in the Python programming language:

content.text: *Set items are unchangeable, but you can remove and/or add items whenever you like.
content.html: *Set items are unchangeable, but you can remove and/or add items whenever you like.

content.text: **As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered . In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered .
content.html: **As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered. In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered.

content.text: When choosing a collection type, it is useful to understand the properties of that type. Choosing the right type for a particular data set could mean retention of meaning, and, it could mean an increase in efficiency or security.
content.html: When choosing a collection type, it is useful to understand the properties of that type. Choosing the right type for a particular data set could mean retention of meaning, and, it could mean an increase in efficiency or security.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which one of these is a tuple?
content.html: Which one of these is a tuple?
